dt: {bc}something apparent to sense but with no substantial existence {bc}{sx|apparition||}
{bc}an object of continual dread or abhorrence
{bc}a representation of something abstract, ideal, or incorporeal

et: Middle English {it}fantesme, fantosme, fantome, fantom{/it} "what only seems to have reality or value, vanity, illusion, apparition, falsehood," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}fantosme, fantasme{/it} {ma}{mat|phantasm|}{/ma}
For the etymological relation between this word and {et_link|phantasm|phantasm}, see the note at the latter word. The spelling with initial {it}ph-{/it} is a restoration from the Greek source.
shortdef: something apparent to sense but with no substantial existence : apparition
an object of continual dread or abhorrence

dt: {bc}of the nature of, suggesting, or being a phantom {bc}{sx|illusory||}

et: Middle English {it}fantom,{/it} from attributive use of {it}fantosme, fantom{/it} {et_link|phantom:1|phantom:1}
shortdef: of the nature of, suggesting, or being a phantom : illusory

dt: {bc}an often painful sensation of the presence of a limb that has been amputated

shortdef: an often painful sensation of the presence of a limb that has been amputated —called also phantom pain

dt: {bc}a medical condition in which a woman believes that she is pregnant and can appear to be pregnant when she is not pregnant

shortdef: a medical condition in which a woman believes that she is pregnant and can appear to be pregnant when she is not pregnant
